title: Cat. 108  Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Oct. 13, 1899
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Oct. 13, 1899  
1899  
Monogram PGO: only state  
Title block: only state  
Mimeograph in brownish-black ink, with wood-block prints in black ink on cream wove paper; 375 × 260 mm (sheet); 32 mm (diameter of printed monogram); 24 × 94 mm (title block)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison Collection, 1948.423  
Kornfeld 56 (monogram), 57 (title block)  
For the inside and back, see fig. 108.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin produced nine issues of Le sourire (The Smile), his “serious newspaper,” as well as three supplements; this is the third issue and contained the second of the three supplements. Using the new technology of mimeography that he encountered while clerking as a draftsman in Papeete, he created the satirical newspaper for local monthly distribution. The machine that Gauguin used was likely an Edison Mimeograph Model 0. These devices were manufactured in Chicago by the A. B. Dick Company and had only become available in 1897. So popular was the machine, which greatly improved the efficiency of bureaucratic offices, that by the time Gauguin gained access to one in 1899, he described it as “all the rage.” It is likely that this duplicating technology also appealed to the artist on a conceptual level, considering his history of experimentation with various transfer processes.

This single sheet represents only the first and second pages of the October 13, 1899, issue. Before entering the museum’s collection the folio was separated along the central fold and the second leaf (pp. 3–4) (see fig. 108.2) and the supplementary leaf (see fig. 108.3) were lost. Originally, the spine edge was the right edge of this extant leaf; the text was read by turning the pages from left to right. This is the second issue containing a supplement, and is the third that Gauguin produced with the hope of using the mimeograph method to print multiples of images as well as the text (see Technical Overview). Unfortunately, the technology had limits that thwarted his aesthetic ambitions; the vignettes sprinkled throughout the text were rendered partially illegible due to broken lines and uneven printing (fig. 108.4). In later issues of the journal, he turned exclusively to wood-block printing for his illustrations. In the Art Institute’s copy of this issue, only the first page is extant.

Gauguin’s lack of success using the Edison mimeograph to reproduce images compelled him to embellish this sheet with the two smallest wood-block prints from the Le sourire series. Here their presence was not an afterthought but was by now predetermined when positioning the text for mimeography. The title block was heavily inked, while a thin application or relatively dry black ink was used for the monogram, yielding a faint impression. The rest of the issue was printed with brownish-black ink applied through a mimeograph stencil. The stencil itself was responsible for the grainy appearance of the text (see Technical Overview).

The paper that Gauguin selected is only slightly higher quality than newsprint. It is a thin, soft, short-fibered paper with a slight texture that is visible in transmitted light. Because the paper was formatted for use with the mimeograph machine and because Gauguin was notoriously low on money and supplies, it is possible that he procured this paper from the office where he worked and where he returned to do his mimeograph printing. This same paper appears again in Gauguin’s later work, including the transfer drawings Woman with a Cat (cat. 123) and Sister of Charity (cat. 125).

375 × 260 mm (sheet); 32 mm (diameter of printed monogram); 24 × 94 mm (title block)

What remains of the issue is in fair condition. At some point it was mended along the edges and central folds. There is some significant staining and discoloration throughout as well as multiple losses in the sheet.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Maurice Gobin (born 1883), Paris, to Carter H. Harrison (1860–1953), June 25, 1948.

Given by Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison, Chicago, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Mimeographed upper left, in brownish-black ink: Gérant / Paul Gauguin

Mimeographed upper center, in brownish-black ink: Le Sourire / Journal Serieux

Mimeographed upper right, in brownish-black ink: 13 Octobre / 3 Raira le numero

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Gauguin gave his publication the subtitle Journal sérieux for the first four months of its production, but by December of 1899, he changed it to Journal méchant (“wicked newspaper”).

Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

For Gauguin’s work in Papeete, see Bengt Danielsson, Gauguin in the South Seas, trans. Reginald Spink (Doubleday, 1964).

“J’ai créé en outre un journal ‘Le Sourire’ autographié Système Edison, qui fait fureur” (I have also created a newspaper, The Smile, using the Edison printing system, which is all the rage). Gauguin to Monfreid, Dec. 1899, in Lettres de Gauguin à Daniel de Monfreid, ed. Annie Joly-Segalen, introduction by Victor Segalen (G. Falaize, 1950), p. 151, no. 59. Translation by the authors.

For more on Gauguin’s experiments with transfer techniques, see Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44. See also Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973).

For the complete Oct. 13, 1899, folio, see also Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

In later issues of the journal, he used wood-block printing exclusively for his illustrations.

Maurice Gobin, receipt dated June 25, 1948, six pages from “Le Sourire,” sold to Mr. Carter H. Harrison, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 108 Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Oct. 13, 1899.

fig. 108.2 The complete folio of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux (Oct. 13, 1899). From Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

fig. 108.3 The supplement to Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux (Oct. 13, 1899). From Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

fig. 108.4 Detail of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux (Oct. 13, 1899, bottom of p. 2) showing the stippled pattern of the mimeographed lines, which lack fluidity and are difficult to read. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.423.

fig. 108.1 Inside and back of Gauguin’s Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Oct. 13, 1899. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.423.

</section>
